image.altText: An old chair with metal legs and a wooden seat and back sits on the dirty floor of a basement. A cobweb extends between corners

items.synopsis: In a basement in a Ukrainian village on the Russian border, the remnants of a torture chamber tell a horrifying tale. Those investigating what happened here say the depraved orders came from the top. WARNING: Readers might find the details in this story distressing.

title.children: When Russians came looking for Vyacheslav, he had already fled. So they took his mum to the torture chamber

image.altText: Close-up of man

items.synopsis: Ben Roberts-Smith has lost one of the most expensive defamation trials in Australia, and along with it his reputation. There are other factors that now need to be considered too.

title.children: Here's what comes next for Ben Roberts-Smith after losing his defamation battle and reputation

image.altText: Half finished shipping container units with broken windows and doors

items.synopsis: Developer Benny Wu is at the centre of legal action over a dilapidated former destination for Hollywood stars as he faces further scrutiny over other run-down properties in Queensland's far north.

title.children: Hong Kong billionaire may lose tropical Queensland island 'jewel' as properties fall into disrepair

image.altText: an aerial image of emergency services responding to a traffic crash on a motorway

items.synopsis: Police allege five boys were travelling in a stolen Mazda when it crashed into another car, closing three of the four southbound lanes of the M1 in peak commuter traffic. Investigators believe three of the teens fled the scene.

title.children: Two teenagers charged over multi-vehicle peak-hour pile-up on the Gold Coast

image.altText: A studio portrait of Australian Army nurse, Vivian Bullwinkel, in service dress uniform

items.synopsis: Vivian Bullwinkel was the sole survivor of a wartime massacre, but the full extent of the horrors she experienced is only now being told.

title.children: 'Tortured and raped': The darker horrors of a WWII massacre revealed

image.altText: A speaker thrusts his arm into the air as thousands of unionists look on at the Domain in Sydney

items.synopsis: The Fair Work Commission announces a 5.75 per cent increase in award wages, while the ASX rises on the back of gains on Wall Street overnight. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Fair Work announces 5.75 per cent rise in award wages; ASX rises as US government looks set to avoid debt default

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you find percentages confusing or don't want to do the math, don't worry — the Fair Work Commission has published its full decision, so we can get an understanding of how much the minimum wage is rising in dollar terms. From July 1, the national minimum wage will be $882.80 a week, or $23.23 an hour. The current national minimum wage is $812.60 per week, or $21.38 an hour. That is an 8.6% increase from July 1. There are some technical reasons why it's higher than the advertised 5.75% rise, which we'll explain in another post.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What is the new hourly rate on the minimum wage?

children.content: If you find percentages confusing or don't want to do the math, don't worry — the Fair Work Commission has published its full decision, so we can get an understanding of how much the minimum wage is rising in dollar terms.
From July 1, the national minimum wage will be
$882.80 a week
, or
$23.23 an hour
The current national minimum wage is
$812.60 per week
, or
$21.38 an hour
That is
an 8.6% increase from July 1
. There are some technical reasons why it's higher than the advertised 5.75% rise, which we'll explain in another post.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market is making a positive start to trade, following the gains on Wall Street overnight. The main S & P 500 index on Wall Street rose 1% after the compromise deal between President Biden and House Speaker McCarthy to suspend the debt ceiling until January 1, 2025 passed the House of Representatives. The ASX 200 index locally jumped 0.6% to 7,156 points in response to those gains, with the broader All Ords up 0.6% as well to 7,336 points by 10:30am AEST.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens higher on Wall Street gains

children.content: The Australian share market is making a positive start to trade, following the gains on Wall Street overnight.
The main S
P 500 index on Wall Street rose 1% after the compromise deal between President Biden and House Speaker McCarthy to suspend the debt ceiling until January 1, 2025 passed the House of Representatives.
The
ASX 200 index locally jumped 0.6% to 7,156 points
in response to those gains, with the broader
All Ords up 0.6% as well to 7,336 points
by 10:30am AEST.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In announcing the decision to increase the minimum wage by 5.75%, the Fair Work Commission explained that it doesn't agree with concerns that a pay rise to Australia's lowest paid workers will result in a "wage price spiral". Here's an excerpt from the Commission's president Adam Hatcher's announcement a short time ago: "As the total wages of modern award reliant workers constitute a limited proportion of the national wage bill, we are confident that the increase we have determined will make only a modest  contribution to total wages growth in 2023-24, and will consequently not cause or contribute to any wage price spiral. "We acknowledge that this  increase will not maintain the real value of modern award minimum wages, nor reverse the reduction real value which has occurred over recent  years. "However, the level of wage  increase we have determined as we  consider the most that can recently be justified in the current economic circumstances. "In the medium to  long-term, it is desirable that  modern award minimum wages maintain their real value and increase in  line with the trend rate of national productivity growth. "A return to  that path is likely to be possible in future reviews."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Minimum wage increase won't add to 'wage price spiral', FWC says

children.content: In announcing the decision to increase the minimum wage by 5.75%, the Fair Work Commission explained that it doesn't agree with concerns that a pay rise to Australia's lowest paid workers will result in a "wage price spiral".
Here's an excerpt from the Commission's president Adam Hatcher's announcement a short time ago:
"As the total wages of modern award reliant workers constitute a limited proportion of the national wage bill, we are confident that the increase we have determined will make
only a modest  contribution to total wages growth
in 2023-24, and will consequently
not cause or contribute to any wage price spiral
"We acknowledge that this  increase
will not maintain the real value of modern award minimum wages
, nor reverse the reduction real value which has occurred over recent  years.
"However, the level of wage  increase we have determined as we  consider the most that
can recently be justified in the current economic circumstances
"In the medium to  long-term, it is desirable that  modern award minimum wages maintain their real value and increase in  line with the trend rate of national productivity growth.
"A return to  that path is likely to be possible in future reviews."

image.altText: Man smiling at a bar.

items.synopsis: Police charge a 24-year-old man with unlawful striking causing death following an alleged violent attack at an event on the Gold Coast.

title.children: Queensland man charged over alleged one-punch attack after 39yo dies

image.altText: Fat, cholesterol and other substances build up in the walls of the arteries, restricting blood flow.

items.synopsis: Peripheral artery disease is described as a "silent killer", but women don't always show traditional symptoms, which is leading to underdiagnosis.

title.children: Danielle was given a choice — her leg or her life. She wants others to recognise the signs of this 'silent killer'

image.altText: An image of Billie Eilish singing into a microphone next to an image of Elton John in pink sunglasses and a dedazzled jacket

items.synopsis: North Queensland once hosted world-renowned artists Elton John and Billie Eilish within months of each other. Now it's being overlooked as the live music industry grapples with an uncertain future.

title.children: It has a $300m stadium and legions of fans, but this city is no longer attracting music royalty

image.altText: a close-up of someone using an iphone to purchase alcohol online

items.synopsis: With concerns about ease of access for underage and binge drinkers, the Queensland government has opened consultations on how regulations impacting the industry could change.

title.children: No ID? No worries: The lack of rules for alcohol delivery services in Queensland has many worried

image.altText: A black red and orange colour scheme featuring quotes and a woman looking at camera. A diagonal red line is present on top

items.synopsis: Quotes from prominent First Nations activists, writers, academics and politicians who have critiqued the notion of a Voice to Parliament have appeared in new No campaign social media ads. But some are not willing participants.

image.altText: A group of solar panels on a roof through the frame of leafy trees.

items.synopsis: Rocketing power prices have reignited interest in rooftop solar, but are low feed-in tariffs discouraging people from taking the plunge?

image.altText: A woman with grey hair pulled back has one hand on the bar and one hand extended in a ballet pose

items.synopsis: They're known as the Silver Swans and their numbers are growing across Australia as dancers enjoy physical and mental health benefits.

image.altText: Australian banknotes, mostly $50 bills, strewn over a flat surface.

items.synopsis: The government's proposal is expected to increase the pay of about 2 per cent of its workforce. These charts show exactly who those staff are.

title.children: Which public servants will receive salary boosts under the plan to fix pay gaps?

image.altText: A NSW player is taken from the field by two trainers during the first Women's State of Origin match.

items.synopsis: Isabelle Kelly gives an update on her condition in hospital, as NSW questions why it was not awarded a penalty following the incident that saw the star centre cough up blood during the Sky Blues' defeat to Queensland in the Women's State of Origin series opener.

items.synopsis: The opening match of the 2023 women's Origin series might have been far from the elite product we have come to know, but it was also proof that it is time for women's rugby league to go to the next level.

title.children: For the success of the women's Origin series to continue the game must be put in a position to succeed

image.altText: A Mac laptop resting on a bed in the dark

items.synopsis: Police will allege the victims handed the money over for investment schemes for their retirement, but the suspect used the money for other purposes.

title.children: 80yo man charged for allegedly scamming $700k from elderly people

items.synopsis: Police are investigating the shooting deaths of a 58-year-old man and a 15-year-old boy in the Northern Rivers region of NSW.

title.children: Man, teenager found dead with gunshot wounds in Yamba home

image.altText: Anthony Albanese mid-sentence while gesturing with his hands, the background is out of focus

items.synopsis: Mr Albanese will give the keynote speech at the Shangri-La Dialogue in front of US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin and China's Defence Minister Li Shangfu.

title.children: Singapore's prime minister pulls out of meeting with Anthony Albanese after COVID test

image.altText: Unidentified woman looking out of her window.

items.synopsis: The neighbour of a Tasmanian woman who starved to death in her own home says the 71-year-old was let down by those who should have stepped in to help her.

title.children: 'Nobody cared to do anything': Suzie says she tried to get help for neighbour who starved to death

image.altText: Charlie Wade stands on a pier

items.synopsis: English backpacker Charlie Wade was surprised when a girl he met on Snapchat asked him to send a nude photo. Her next message left him in a state of shock.

title.children: Charlie is one of a growing number of young men falling victim to 'sextortion' scams — he wants you to learn from his mistakes

items.synopsis: Authorities in western Mexico find 45 bags containing human remains in a gorge on the outskirts of Guadalajara and are trying to determine how many bodies there are.

title.children: Authorities in western Mexico find 45 bags with human remains

image.altText: Armie Hammer at the Hollywood Film Awards in 2018, wearing a black blazer and a white skiv

items.synopsis: A woman accused the actor of sexually assaulting her in 2017.

title.children: 'Name has been cleared': Sexual assault charges dropped against Armie Hammer

image.altText: Four young children smiling and laughing

items.synopsis: Charmaine Harris McLeod, her two daughters, Aaleyn, 6, and Matilda, 5, and her two sons Wyatt, 4, and Zaidok, 2, died after their car collided with a truck near Kingaroy in May, 2019.

title.children: Inquest hears Charmaine McLeod claimed husband raped her and her children in years prior to fatal crash

image.altText: A large circular CSIRO logo on the side of a building.

title.children: CSIRO deputy chair David Knox overpaid by $200,000, money still unrecovered

image.altText: A woman sits at a computer with her hair shielding her face, drinking a coffee.

items.synopsis: International students say tools to detect AI-generated text are inaccurate, as a US study suggests the detectors are biased against people writing in English as a second language.

title.children: 'A huge impact on our study': Chinese students in Australia navigate challenges posed by AI detectors

image.altText: A tattoo of a man in a bandanna on a leg.

items.synopsis: The WA premier's handling of the pandemic inspired tattoos and even a cereal brand, but what else will people remember him for, and what issues remain unresolved?

title.children: It's Mark McGowan's last day as premier. So what will he be remembered for?

image.altText: Stacey Gaspero in her backyard.

items.synopsis: A local business in Tasmania began mowing lawns free of charge after noticing a lot of clients simply couldn't afford their services — for Stacey Gaspero, it may just have saved her from being evicted.

title.children: Stacey's garden was so overgrown she feared eviction — then a stranger stepped in

image.altText: A woman looking at an iPhone XS

items.synopsis: Mental health apps have flourished in the gaps within mental healthcare. But the products are also exempt from regulations in Australia, with some experts concerned about user safety.

title.children: Fake reviews, celebrity deals and no evidence base: The 'very strange' world of mental health apps

image.altText: A PwC logo on the side of a building.

items.synopsis: By coincidence, the furore around the consultancy firm PwC is raging just as the National Anti-Corruption Commission is gearing up for its start of business on July 1.

title.children: A coincidence is playing out in Canberra, and a new player might have spotted its first target

image.altText: Rory, wearing a school tie and blazer, holds a guitar.

items.synopsis: At just 16, songwriter Rory Phillips is challenging the centuries-old view that the strong, silent bloke is the epitome of Australian manhood.

title.children: 'It's still a bit taboo': Rory's song challenges views about manhood he says need to change

image.altText: Spider-Man, an animated figure in a skin-tight blue and red body suit leaps through the air against a cityscape.

items.synopsis: Across the Spider-Verse serves up more variations on the character — and more dazzling visuals — than a spider-man could point his finger at. But it's not just eager to please.

title.children: Latest Spider-Man movie is a dazzling, inventive and often hilarious challenge to the status quo
